componenttextpreview: I was wondering whether if I could touch that one more time, like the issues in like North American Flavors, and that is if you strip out the acquisition benefit, the North American Flavors business was down, whether that could maybe 4%. And I know you gr
componenttext: I was wondering whether if I could touch that one more time, like the issues in like North American Flavors, and that is if you strip out the acquisition benefit, the North American Flavors business was down, whether that could maybe 4%. And I know you grew very strongly in the first quarter, but even if you average it out, it means that maybe you grew 3% on a local currency basis excluding acquisitions. And last year you were down 4%. And your comparisons in the fourth quarter are becoming difficult again because there was volume growth of 7%. And obviously, there are some implications to the -- to EBIT level as well because your sales -- your overall Flavor sales this quarter dropped $3 million but your EBIT was down $7 million. And so I was wondering whether you can sort of like shed some thought on that as like, what the issues are on the North American Flavors business and why you're confident that, outside of cost control, things should be better in the back half of the year? And secondly, I was wondering like how much of your share repurchase program you may complete in '15 and in '16?

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Matthias speaking. Let me answer the first question. H1, year-to-date, our number for North America, we are up. We are growing low single-digit. We had challenges in the second quarter indeed, and particularly, as outlined before in the cate
componenttext: Okay. This is Matthias speaking. Let me answer the first question. H1, year-to-date, our number for North America, we are up. We are growing low single-digit. We had challenges in the second quarter indeed, and particularly, as outlined before in the category of Savory. We also recognize that the larger accounts, the very large international accounts, where we have a very high index in North America, they are not growing as fast as the smaller, more agile companies, which are probably more the medium manufacturers in the food and beverage industry. It's exactly the reason and part of the strategic rationale why IFF had a very strong interest, and we're still very pleased and privileged to have Ottens being part of our portfolio. It will give us a vehicle where we can differentiate ourselves, where we can keep the agility, the speed, the responseness (sic) [responsiveness] and the ownership for those accounts to make tailored solutions, which have a faster growth rate in North America. So overall, I feel confident that we will be posting full year growth, excluding Ottens like-for-like still. And I believe together with Ottens, we will further accelerate in the quarters to come. Okay? Share repurchase?

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sure. In terms of share repurchase, for the remainder of 2015, we would expect to spend about $40 million to $50 million, and then $100 million each year thereafter.
componenttext: Okay. Sure. In terms of share repurchase, for the remainder of 2015, we would expect to spend about $40 million to $50 million, and then $100 million each year thereafter.

componenttext: So I wanted to talk about Latin America. I know you mentioned that this was the seventh quarter of double-digit growth in Flavors, in particular. So and I know you talked about a delivery system. So I was wondering if you could expand on that a little bit? I know the categories you mentioned were Beverages, in particular, but it would be helpful to learn more about who these customers are, are you gaining share, or is market growth just as strong, just anything else that you can add to that?

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you for the question. I certainly believe we are gaining in Latin America. It's not the confidence that we are posting the seventh consecutive double-digit quarter. We are really traveling well. Our approach to pipeline is very strong. And whe
componenttext: Well, thank you for the question. I certainly believe we are gaining in Latin America. It's not the confidence that we are posting the seventh consecutive double-digit quarter. We are really traveling well. Our approach to pipeline is very strong. And when I was referring to our unit delivery station technology, I'm referring here to a product which increases authenticity, naturalness of the taste. And it's mainly used, not only, but mainly used in Beverages.  In addition, we have a lot of great inroads we made in other categories such as Savory. Thanks again to our technologies in Savory modulation. And frankly, I feel very good about our performance, even going forwards, and it makes us feel good that we are investing in Vision 2020, in exactly those areas which are truly differentiating ourselves from competition.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are the customers, is it a mix of multinational and local customers? Or is there more contribution from one of those?
componenttext: Okay. And are the customers, is it a mix of multinational and local customers? Or is there more contribution from one of those?

componenttext: Yes, good morning, John. It's -- you have a briefing process, but the active ingredients is very much innovation-led. We would expect, through the balance of the summer, to probably have some news in September, probably middle to end of September.

componenttext: So I mean -- this is Alison. So there was an impact, and I'd say the biggest impact in terms of offsetting that profitability going to the bottom line was increased incentive compensation. Beyond that, we had the intangible impact of $1.2 million was also mentioned. And that was somewhat offset by productivity and cost control initiatives, but that was the biggest -- those were the 2 biggest impacts. And then we also mentioned China, which is also included as a negative impact from the bottom line.

componenttext: Well, Mike, we expect to have continued additional cost in China, also in Q3 and for H2, in general. I -- it is all factored into our forecast, though. They will not be higher than what we had for the quarter in Q2. In terms of productivity, it is very high on our agenda. It obviously depends upon a lot on how can we can possibly further accelerate our top line. While we are still early in the quarter, I feel good that we will deliver solid top line growth that can offset some of the pressures Alison has alluded to before.

componenttextpreview: As you know, encapsulation has been really one of the key drivers of the continued growth and success in Consumer Fragrances. So I would say the majority of the revenues from encapsulation at this stage are really in Fabric Care. But it's really one of th
componenttext: As you know, encapsulation has been really one of the key drivers of the continued growth and success in Consumer Fragrances. So I would say the majority of the revenues from encapsulation at this stage are really in Fabric Care. But it's really one of the key pillars of the driver -- and driver of our Vision 2020. That's where we are really investing significantly right now, in resources and capacity. And with a goal obviously to enlarge the offering to other category. So we have early success in other categories. We're pleased. That's why it's growing fast, because it's on a small base. So for the foreseeable future, we think the growth will be coming from Fabric augmented possibly with other categories.

I know you have slightly revised the sales guidance towards the low end. So obviously, within that, what you're sort of seeing today relative to what you were seeing, maybe, 3 or 6 months ago, and how you sort of think about that normalizing over time.

componenttext: Okay. So first, let me answer the interest-related question. It'll be a $2 million increase, which was included in our guidance. So that's reflective. So we expect the short-term -- or this year's performance to be in line with our long-term guidance of 4% to 6%. We still believe that's the case albeit at the low end of the range due to pressure from Ingredients, which Nicolas had spoken about as well as some uncertainly in Fine Fragrance.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Talking about China, basically, we see the same. We see challenges as well. And we see mainly very large international accounts being challenged. We see volumes decreasing. We see retail destocking. And the [indiscernible] states as well and the -- mainly
componenttext: Talking about China, basically, we see the same. We see challenges as well. And we see mainly very large international accounts being challenged. We see volumes decreasing. We see retail destocking. And the [indiscernible] states as well and the -- mainly has a similar symptom as we have in North America, that smaller accounts seems to be more agile and probably have softer innovative solutions, which are more tailored for the market in China. As we are there, we try to expand. We work with the commercial team in China to increase our customer portfolio and to ensure that we are, again, more relevant in the marketplace. I, however, would like to remind that we see challenges in China. We have comparables, what we are comparing to last year, irrespective of whether it's Q2 or even H1, we are comparing to very solid single-digit growth. So we mainly had a slowed down the last 3 quarters in China.

componenttextpreview: It's Silke Kueck, one more time, for Jeff. I was wondering whether you can just share your thoughts in sort of, like, the competitive environment, and that is the -- it is obviously now like a new entrant in the industry, with ADM acquiring Wild Flavors.
componenttext: It's Silke Kueck, one more time, for Jeff. I was wondering whether you can just share your thoughts in sort of, like, the competitive environment, and that is the -- it is obviously now like a new entrant in the industry, with ADM acquiring Wild Flavors. Like it seems as sort of like a roll-up on a -- in the food industry, Heinz acquired Kraft, and like Tyson's acquiring Hillshire Brands. In the Fragrance industry, P&G is divesting its beauty cup business, and that's going now to Coty. So I was wondering whether you can discuss a little bit like what the competitive trends are like.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you for the question. I think what we experience these days is what will probably start with the years and [indiscernible] a long time ago. We see consolidation on the account base. I think consolidation is such that the account is also a grea
componenttext: Well, thank you for the question. I think what we experience these days is what will probably start with the years and [indiscernible] a long time ago. We see consolidation on the account base. I think consolidation is such that the account is also a great opportunity for us. It's really an opportunity to ensure that we are truly partnering at a very early stage. And I outlined once at the Investor's Day, as soon as we are partnering at a very early stage with our customers, our win rates and the chance that we are really submitting a value creation and value addition to them is much higher. Nowadays, our customers, they are not looking for vendors and suppliers anymore, they are really looking for true partners. And we see this is a great opportunity. When it comes to North America, what we outlined with Ottens, we all said we want to create a vehicle for us to truly differentiate ourselves, to keep the agility, the speed, the ownership. But the downfall [ph], the very long-standing history, Ottens has built here in North America and to back it together with latest technology from IFF. We affirm the belief that this will help us to accelerate our growth rates to penetrate into a segment that is growing faster of what we believe than the very large accounts in North America and see it as a great opportunity. Maybe Nicolas, you want to add something, provide some color on Fragrance?

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Silke, it's Nicolas. A very similar trend in terms of the customer dynamic moving to strategic partnership. So every consolidation provide additional upside opportunities. And here, it is obviously -- or you need to support and provide consumer insig
componenttext: Yes, Silke, it's Nicolas. A very similar trend in terms of the customer dynamic moving to strategic partnership. So every consolidation provide additional upside opportunities. And here, it is obviously -- or you need to support and provide consumer insight and to identify growth opportunities for the portfolios and reaching significant scale. So we believe it is a positive outlook for us.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Flavors & Fragrances Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Michael DeVeau, Vice President, Global Corporate Communications and
componenttext: At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Flavors & Fragrances Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Michael DeVeau, Vice President, Global Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon, and good evening everyone. Welcome to IFF's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday, we distributed our press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found on our IR website at
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon, and good evening everyone. Welcome to IFF's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday, we distributed our press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found on our IR website at iff.com. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay. Please take a moment to review our forward-looking statements. During the call, we will be making forward-looking statements about the company's performance, particularly with regard to our outlook for the fourth quarter and full year of 2015. These statements are based on how we see things today and contain elements of uncertainty. For additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from forward-looking statements, please refer to our cautionary statement and risk factors contained in our 10-K filed on March 2, 2015, and our press release that we filed yesterday. 
Today's presentation will include non-GAAP financial measures, which excludes those items that we believe affect comparability. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their respective GAAP measures is set forth in our press release. 
With me on the call today is our Chairman and CEO, Andreas Fibig; our Executive Vice President and CFO, Alison Cornell; our Group President of Flavors, Matthias Haeni; and our Group President of Fragrances, Nicolas Mirzayantz. We will start with prepared remarks from Andreas and Alison and then the entire team will be available for any questions that you may have. 
Before turning the call over to Andreas, I would like to let you know that we continue to explore options to improve our liquidity on [indiscernible] Paris. We remain optimistic that we can enhance our liquidity in Euronex to allow more European investors access to our shares. We will continue to keep you updated on our progress as we move forward. 
With that, I would like to now introduce our Chairman and CEO, Andreas Fibig.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I would like to start by providing an executive overview of our operational performance this quarter. In addition, similar how we structured the quarter conference call I want to provide an update on the execution of our 4 pillar Vision 2
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I would like to start by providing an executive overview of our operational performance this quarter. In addition, similar how we structured the quarter conference call I want to provide an update on the execution of our 4 pillar Vision 2020 strategy. Once finished, I will ask Alison to review our financial results in greater detail, including the specifics on each business unit as well as our cash flow statements and our outlook for the balance of the year.
I'm pleased to report that our financial results for the third quarter accelerated versus our second quarter performance, both in terms of currency neutral sales and currency neutral operating profit growth, as we continue to benefit from diversity of our business as well as our recent acquisitions. 
Currency neutral sales in the third quarter improved 7%, including approximately 3 percentage points relating to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors and Lucas Meyer cosmetics. Organic top line performance, which increased 4% this quarter continue to be driven by new wins, particularly in Fragrance Compounds with a contribution of new wins were at the highest level in nearly 2 years.
This favorable to profitability as adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS post 10% on a currency-neutral basis. On a year-to-date basis, results remained strong. As currency neutral sales growing 6% comprised of 8% growth in Flavors and 5% growth in Fragrances. 
For the first 9 months in 2015, consolidated adjusted operating profit increased 9% on currency-neutral basis, driven by sales growth, the benefit of productivity programs and manufacturing and cost leverage. 
Complementing our expansion in gross margin and adjusted operating profit margin, lower interest expense, a more favorable effect of tax rate and a reduction of our shares outstanding led to an 11% increase on our currency neutral adjusted EPS.
On a strategic perspective, I would like to talk about a couple of areas. In the areas where we are targeting a market leadership position defined by #1 or 2 market share position, we believe we are taking it with steps to deliver on our Division of accelerated growth. 
In North America Flavors team has done a nice job integrating our recent activation of Ottens Flavors, leveraging their go-to-market strategy, which focuses on winning this key regional accounts in the U.S. Our Flavors North America business was up 19%. 
In Flavors Latin America, our proprietary delivery system continues to perform well as evidence with its eighth consecutive quarter of double-digit growth. In the third quarter, growth was very strong, up 20% on a currency-neutral basis. 
Within Fragrance, North America Fragrance Compounds grew 7% with 8% growth in Consumer Fragrances and a 4% growth in Fine Fragrances. The quarter's subcategory performance that were most notable in North America were Hair Care and Home Care, both of which grew double digits, plus Fabric Care, which grew high single digits.
In the third quarter, China Fragrances, another area where we have ambitions to accelerate gross, was 6% on a currency-neutral basis as we continue to have success with many of the strong regional Consumer Fragrances brands. 
From a category perspective, Home Care, another area of focus for us, improved high single digits globally on a currency natural basis led by double-digit growth in North America and Latin America. 
Delivery systems across both Flavors and Fragrance continues to drive growth with strong trends in Fabric Care and Beverage continued in the third quarter, driven by our industry-leading encapsulation technology in Fragrances and proprietary delivery systems in Flavors.
Fabric Care grew double digits on a currency natural basis in the third quarter with all geographic markets posting strong growth. This is a direct result of our differentiated encapsulation technology. 
Given our success in Fabric Care, we have begun to expand into other categories as well. In the third quarter, while still early in terms of strategic execution, we have seen strong results in encapsulation-related sales and Toiletries and Home Care, both, which grew double digits. 
Supporting the expansion of this technology into more are categories, our R&D team developed the next-generation capsule technology that allows us to further penetrate personal care applications. This technology should allow us to efficiently customer solutions to deliver Fragrance at the points desired by consumers.
In Fragrances, building on our legacy of pioneering price, one of our Vision 2020 goals is to launch more new captive molecules to give our perfumers a competitive edge when creating the next-generation Fragrance. Tracking this initiative, we have recently launched 2 new highly anticipated ingredients to our perfumers, customer food, which is a high impact complex fruity with spicy undertones and Crystal, which is watery refresh note, to be used is internally by our perfumers as exclusive IFF molecules, which we are not selling externally.
And as we look to the fourth quarter, we expect to commercialize 2 additional molecules, which will bring our commercialize molecules to 4 this year. If successful, this would effectively put us on track to double our annual Fragrance molecule output average order plus decade [ph] providing us with greater confidence in our accelerated growth ambition.
As I mentioned moments ago in Flavors, our proprietary delivery system continues to perform well. This technology is expanding beyond just Latin America this proprietary the delivery system related to sales going strong double digits globally. 
Sales of our sweetness and savor modulation portfolio continue to produce strong results, increasing strong double digits. 
At categories where we had the most success were Savory, Dairy and Beverage as our innovative solutions are allowing our customers to meet the demands of the consumers who are looking for better-for-you products, including reduced sugar and salt. 
To complement this, I'm pleased to announce that we have also commercialize a new natural place modulator, the second one this year, which is a [indiscernible] designed to reduce the salt perception without changing the product's acidity particularly useful for yogurts and juice applications. This addition will strengthen our modulation capabilities as it provides our Flavors a more competitive to build winning solutions.
Building on a very robust technology pipeline is critical. The third quarter is an example that we are making strong progress against key initiatives that will lead to greater differentiation and ultimately accelerated growth.
In addition to the strikes we have made from market share and perspective, we also make progress in our never-ending quest to become our customers' partner of choice. To meet the growing trends in naturals in October 2015, IFF LMR Naturals received its fourth For Life social responsibility designation, this time in corporation with our Haiti. The For Life recognizes an organization's adherence to specific sustainability criteria, including transparency, environmental responsibility, fair working conditions and positive relations with producers and local communities. This recognition comes after certification of IFF-LMR Naturals for the supply chain in Turkey and is basel supply chain in Madagascar.
When it comes to sustainability, we won't accept the status quo while. Recently, we begin the first Flavors and Fragrance company to join DFS and growing consortium of a multinational companies committed to ensuring sustainable practices throughout the supply chain.
We also are recognized by the CDP earning a perfect score of 100 in disclosure and in A performance for its strategies and actions to mitigate climate change. Sustainability is a foundational to our Vision 2020 business strategy, and we are committed to embedding business throughout our business practices and our corporate culture for the years to come.
We are won North American innovation award with a one of our largest Flavors customers, which recognize the partners for their leadership. In addition, Este Lauder also presented us with the supplier's excellence award, an achievement designed to acknowledge their top-performing business partners.
I'm pleased to also announce that at the 2015 in cosmetics Asia Lucas Meyer Cosmetics won the Gold award for the innovation the best active Ingredients with the XO be, a ingredient designed to rapidly improve dull skin for healthy looking complexion in only 7 days and also won the Gold award of innovation best possible Ingredients with, an Ingredients scientifically measured think there is a tick next developed by specialists and psychology and neuroscience, which provides positive emotion upon application.
With a focus on the future and in terms of the business participation in years to come, we also reaffirm an expanded core with key Flavors customers 2 based in North America and one globally and also a large Fragrance customer in the third quarter.
As you know, [indiscernible] are paramount to winning future business within our industry. Being added to a near [indiscernible] that we are able to bring the right R&D capabilities consumer insights, regulatory requirements and customers to resonate at to create a winning products in the marketplace.
During the second and third quarter, we completed 2 acquisitions, which focus on strengthening and expanding our portfolio. I'm pleased to reported that both acquisitions are performing very well. Ottens Flavors organic sales on a stand-alone basis increased low double digits, above our North America-based business, which improved substantially. And Lucas Meyer's cosmetics achieved strong double digit currency neutral sales growth on a stand-alone basis. We believe these results are good indication that we are putting our capital to work to drive accelerated performance in terms of growth and returns.
Following the end of the third quarter, we also announced the partnership with the [indiscernible] communications to pioneer the digital future of scent, combining certain [indiscernible] software platform with the IFF technology and expertise. The collaboration anticipated to bring mobile scent experiences to consumers. And while this is an initial step, we believe the technologies developed by Vapor Communications will play an important role in our larger digital scent journey in Vision 2020.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Alison who will take you through the financials in greater detail.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andreas. Looking at our third quarter results, similar to what I did on our Q2 conference call, I want to continue to lay out a bridge from our adjusted financial results to our adjusted currency neutral results.In the first column, which is
componenttext:
Thank you, Andreas. Looking at our third quarter results, similar to what I did on our Q2 conference call, I want to continue to lay out a bridge from our adjusted financial results to our adjusted currency neutral results.
In the first column, which is inclusive of currency, sales contracted by 1%, while adjusted operating profit increased 7% and adjusted EPS grew 5%.
Consistent with what we communicated previously, in the third quarter, we benefited from our euro transactional hedging program, which ultimately protected our euro-denominated profit. Including this benefit, our growth rate in terms of adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS accelerated to 7% and 5% versus the 1% and 4% we reported in the first half, respectively. Yet, even with the benefits of hedging, foreign exchange still proved to be a headwind in the third quarter as the U.S. dollar remained strong against many global currencies. 
From a sales adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS perspective, currency represented an 8, 3 and 5 percentage point impact respectively. 
On a currency-neutral basis, we continue to deliver strong results, achieving leverage within our P&L with the sales improving 7% and adjusted operating profit going 10%. The increase in adjusted operating profit was driven by gross margin expansion and cost leverage, which led to an approximately 50 basis point improvement in currency neutral adjusted operating profit margin.
Currency neutral adjusted EPS also improved by 10% as the year-over-year decrease in our average shares outstanding resulting from our share repurchase program offset a slightly higher effective tax rate and an increase in interest expense relating to both of our acquisitions. The acquisitions we made earlier this year are adding to our performance, evidenced that we are investing in strategic value-add opportunities that deliver high return
In the third quarter, the acquisitions of Ottens and Lucas Meyer's added approximately 3 points to currently currency neutral sales growth, about 2 points to currency neutral adjusted operating profit and 3 points to currency neutral adjusted EPS growth. It should be noted that the amortization of intangibles relating to the Ottens and Lucas Meyer acquisition represented about $3.5 million in the quarter.
If we add this back to understand the cash component of the business, adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS growth would have improved another 2 percentage points to 12%, respectively, on a currency-neutral basis.
[indiscernible] here, I would like to provide you with some insight into the trends we saw throughout the quarter. In September, while at the sell side Investor Conference, I made some cautionary comments relating to our organic business. Following the Chinese currency devaluation, we saw several customers it take a more cautious approach to managing their inventory, which ultimately meant sequential softness as we progress through the quarter. This perpetuated, particularly in emerging markets, which while still positive up 3% in Q3 were slower than our first half performance of 8%, despite relatively strong performance in Latin America. And while we remain fully committed to the long-term growth of these key market, in the short-term, we are working to manage the uncertainty and focusing of the leverage we can pull to deliver results and strengthen our business.
Fortunately, we experienced strong orders in the last week the quarter leading to the 4% organic growth rate we reported in Q3 ahead of where we thought we would finish the quarter.
Turning to business unit performance. Flavors posted its 43rd consecutive quarter of growth, increasing 8%, including approximately 4.5 percentage points relating to the acquisitions of Ottens Flavors. All categories experienced broad-based growth with the strongest results in Beverage and Dairy.
In our Europe, Africa and Middle East region, sales increased 4%, led by high single-digit growth in Beverage. Western Europe reported the highest growth, improving 9% driven by strong performance.
North America grew 19%, reflecting additional sales and related to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors and high double-digit growth in Dairy. If we exclude the benefit of Ottens organic performance improved sequentially versus Q2, up low single-digits.
Latin America increased 20% as all categories reported positive growth. The strong double-digit trend in Beverage continued for the eighth consecutive quarter, led by our proprietary delivery system. Savory and Dairy also grew double digits as a result of strong new win performance, which leverages the proprietary delivery systems as well as our modulation portfolio.
Greater Asia remains constant as growth in Indonesia, India, Singapore and Japan was offset by softness in China, which was primarily driven by a challenging economic environment your
Flavors currency neutral segment profit improved approximately 9% as gross margin expansion and cost and productivity benefits more than offset the inclusion of amortization of intangibles related to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors. This led to a 10 basis point improvement in operating profit margin, despite incremental cost in Q3 relating to the China issue. If we exclude this impact, our operating margin would have expended by 80 basis points in the third quarter or growth would have been 12%. It should be noted however, that we expect a portion of this expense to continue as we work through this issue. Specifically, in Q4, we would expect a similar impact in terms of expense as we experienced in Q3. 
Fragrances currency neutral sales improved 6%, including approximately 2 percentage points associated with the acquisition of Lucas Meyer Cosmetics with all regions posting growth, led by high single-digit growth in Latin America and mid-single-digit improvement in Greater Asia.
From a category perspective, Fine Fragrance was up 1% led by Europe, Africa and the Middle East, which improved 5% as a result of very strong pipeline of new wins, including Olympia by Popper upon, by Proctor & Gamble, by from L'Oreal and Jimmy Choo by
In Latin America, economic conditions, particularly in Brazil, continue to have an impact on discretionary spending and ultimately, our fine Fragrance performance. Yet, while sales are down, they improved versus the second quarter and even as economies fall, we continue to see our win rate remain high, which we believe will support our market leadership position us of the economy stabilizes.
I also wanted to put our Fine Fragrance results in Greater Asia into perspective relative to our global Fragrance business. Unfortunately, Greater Asia Fine Fragrances represented approximately 2% of our global fine Fragrance sales, which means quarterly order patterns can have a substantial impact on growth rates as it did in Q1 with Fine Fragrance in Greater Asia was up almost 40%.
And as the market relatively small in terms of per capita uses now, we believe it will increase over time as we stated in our Vision 2020 strategy. 
For the 16th consecutive quarter, Consumer Fragrances continue to grow, up 7% with mid- to high single digits in every region and broad-based category growth led by double-digit growth in Fabric Care and high single-digit growth in Hair Care.
In Fabric, thanks in large part to a local knowledge of the consumer and our encapsulated technology, growth was strongest in Greater Asia where we are winning with local customers. And in Hair Care, growth was of the best in Latin America as we have the ability to offer exceptional Fragrances in nontraditional category said that with the consumer's desire for lower-cost alternatives.
Fragrance Ingredients sales were up 6%, driven by the acquisition of Lucas Meyer Cosmetics, which closed on July 30. Sales cosmetic active grew high double digit in Brazil, Japan, Indonesia and the U.S., all as a result of new wins. 
Our base Fragrance Ingredients business, which as a reminder are the external sales that we do not use for our internal company's predictions, remain soft, reflecting more challenging conditions, including our largest Fragrance Ingredients customer, rationalizing their portfolio as well as our prioritization of capacity to further strengthen our internal Fragrance Compounds business as evidenced by high single-digit internal demand growth.
On a profit perspective, Fragrance currency neutral segment profit improved approximately 15%, driven by volume growth and benefits from cost and productivity initiatives. This performance, plus lower incentive compensation expense, was over 150 basis point improvement in operating profit margin. 
From a cash flow perspective, our core working capital level continue to show improvement as a percent of sales versus the same period of 2014 as our 5 quarter rolling average figure through the end of the third quarter was down 80 basis points to approximately 28.8% of our trailing 12-month sales.
All of our gains versus the first 9 months of 2014 came from lower payables as our days payable outstanding increased 9% versus the same period a year ago. 
Operating cash flow from operations at the end of the third quarter was $295 million, including an incremental $27 million pension contributions over this year. Excluding the incremental pension contribution, operating cash flow would have increased $322 million or 40 basis points in terms of adjusted operating cash flow as a percentage of sales and 13.6% during the first 9 months of 2014 to 14% for the equivalent period in 2015.
Looking at our uses of cash. Capital expenditure on a year-to-date basis is $67 million or 2.9% of sales as we continue to make investments to support our growth initiatives, principally as we finish our plants in Turkey and Indonesia. And while we are a little low on the capital spend year-to-date relative to our full year guidance, we expect to finish approximately 4.5% as spending traditionally falls through during the fourth quarter each year.
For cash returned to shareholders, we expect to continue to deliver a total payout ratio in line with our 50% to 60% target, all while maintaining financial flexibility to capitalize organic growth opportunities and value-creating M&A. 
Dividend payments year-to-date have been $114 million following our 20% increase this past August. Share repurchases at the end of the quarter were $81 million, allowing us to buy back approximately 726,000 shares at an average price of $111.88 per share. Please note that as of Friday, we have repurchased approximately $21 million of shares since the end of the quarter, bringing our year-to-date total to $102 million.
From a guidance perspective, we are reconfirming our full year 2015 guidance despite the challenging year-ago fourth quarter comparison, which includes approximately 200 basis points of growth related to the 53rd week as well as continued to market uncertainty, which is leading to volatility in order patterns for many of our multinational customers.
Despite continued growth in Latin America and Europe, Africa and the Middle East driven by new wins, our core Flavors business is expected to be soft in the fourth quarter. 
In North America, we expect pressure due a to higher level of volume erosion as a businesses want in previous years are not performing at the same levels that they have historically. We are also seeing general weakness in North America with several of our food and beverage customers reporting volume challenges. 
In Greater Asia, we expect similar trends in the third quarter as we believe economic uncertainty in China will continue to impact our business.
In core Fragrances, we expect continued pressure in Fragrance Ingredients, primarily related to the largest customer continuing its rationalization of their portfolio. 
In Fragrance Compounds, we expect that our strong year-ago comparison, the weakness in the Brazilian economy and our strong year-to-date performance, particularly in Consumer Fragrances, will lead to growth moderating in Q4. Fortunately, we expect to benefit from our recent acquisition, which we believe should lead to moderate currency neutral sales growth in the fourth quarter.
In terms of profitability, on a full year basis, we continue to believe we can achieve approximately 9% growth on a currency-neutral basis. The drivers of the profitability performance includes top line growth, benefit of productivity initiatives, lower incentive compensation expense and the inclusion of acquisition.
Stretching our performance to include the impact of currency, the strengthening U.S. dollar versus many global currencies will have an impact. The weakening euro versus the U.S. dollar, which represents our large currency exposure at about 40% of operating profit is expected to have the greatest impact. In addition, several other currencies, while small in terms of profitability exposure, has all weakened considerably versus the U.S. dollar and are collectively pressuring profitability. Mitigating this exposure, we expect approximately a 3 percentage point gain from our transactional euro hedging program. Incorporating the foreign exchange impact on our full year guidance, we would expect reported sales to be down approximately 1%, including approximately a 7 percentage point impact from currency as we do not hedge our translational exposure. From an adjusted operating profit perspective, we expect about a 4% increase, despite an approximately 5 percentage point headwind of currency. 
With that, I would like to turn the call back over to Andreas.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alison. I briefly want to reiterate that despite ongoing volatility in several key markets around the world, we were able to move a strong financial results in the third quarter, thanks in large part to the diversity of our business as well as
componenttext:
Thank you, Alison. I briefly want to reiterate that despite ongoing volatility in several key markets around the world, we were able to move a strong financial results in the third quarter, thanks in large part to the diversity of our business as well as the benefits associated with our recent acquisitions. Also, based on our strong year-to-date results and our outlook for the fourth quarter, we continue to believe we can deliver 6% currency neutral sales growth and approximately 9% adjusted operating profit growth, both on a currency-neutral basis.
Going forward, continuing our execution all of Vision 2020 is top priority for us. Vision 2020 is focused on increasing differentiation, accelerated profitable growth and creating shareholder value, all 3 of which we believe are achievable in the years to come.
With that, I would now like to open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: So Mark, let me talk first about -- so in Q3, our adjusted gross profit margin expanded 170 basis points and this was driven by our currency hedging benefits as we hedge our raw material purchases to protect our transactional exposure as well as our cost
componenttext: So Mark, let me talk first about -- so in Q3, our adjusted gross profit margin expanded 170 basis points and this was driven by our currency hedging benefits as we hedge our raw material purchases to protect our transactional exposure as well as our cost of productivity savings, volume growth and mix improvement. In Q3, there was roughly $9.5 million benefit from our hedge, which was included in the gross -- in our gross profit. This accounted for the majority of the expansion, but there was also benefit is a mission from cost of productivity savings, volume growth and mix improvement. As we move into Q4, we expect our currency hedging benefit to be a little less than half of the expansion in Q4 what with the other half coming from cost of productivity savings initiatives, modest volume growth and M&A. We believe that our -- there is sustainability of that gross margin expansion excluding the FX hedge as we enter into Q4. As we look [indiscernible] 2016, from a raw materials perspective, based on what we've seen so far, it's similar to 2015 where we've seen natural are up, synthetics are slightly down and if anything, we're probably flat to slightly up.

componenttext: So Lauren, let me talk a bit about that. And so as we indicated our Investor Day that we intend to finance our M&A activity through balance sheet leverage and so between us and Lucas Meyer's acquisition, we executed about $500 million in acquisitions. Initially, these are paid for using our existing credit facility and on-hand cash and now, we're looking at longer term financing opportunities to better align our maturities with the nature of those acquisitions. So in September, we entered into interest swaps in anticipation of a long-term debt financing and the deferred to charges and that a table in our 10-Q are being accounted for right now is a hedging instrument as they're related to these swaps. We still are in of the process of evaluating our options for financing and at this point, we haven't finalized the timing or nature of the financing, and we expect to have more clarity on that in Q1 of next year.

We see countries in Asia with strong growth for both businesses. And we see Europe at least on for our business recovering as well. So at the end of the day, it's a very mixed picture region-by-region. The only thing, which is probably universal is that the volume is, for some of the global customers, is really challenged. So that's how we would comment on that one. So it's a very different and it depends also on the technology and let me elaborate on that. A view of a technology, which helps the customers to grow the business like our sweetness modulation for example, which we are selling very well, or the encapsulation of the Fragrances side, then the wins are strong and that even against the market a trend make great strides. I know it's probably not a general satisfying answer, but it is a very diverse picture we are giving this year.

componenttext: At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Flavors & Fragrances Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Michael DeVeau, Vice President, Global Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon, and good evening, everyone. Welcome to IFF's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday, we distributed our press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found in our IR website at
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon, and good evening, everyone. Welcome to IFF's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday, we distributed our press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found in our IR website at iff.com. Please note that this call is being recorded and will be available for replay. Please take a moment to review our forward-looking statements. During the call, we will be making forward-looking statements about the company's performance, particularly with regard to our outlook for the fourth quarter and full year of 2015. These statements are based on how we see things today and contain elements of uncertainty. For additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from forward-looking statements, please refer to our cautionary statement and risk factors contained in our 10-K filed on March 2, 2015, and our press release that we filed yesterday. 
Today's presentation will include non-GAAP financial measures, which excludes those items that we believe affect comparability. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their respective GAAP measures is set forth in our press release. 
With me on the call today is our Chairman and CEO, Andreas Fibig; our Executive Vice President and CFO, Alison Cornell; our Group President of Flavors, Matthias Haeni; and our Group President of Fragrances, Nicolas Mirzayantz. We will start with prepared remarks from Andreas and Alison and then the entire team will be available for any questions that you may have. 
Before turning the call over to Andreas, I would like to let you know that we continue to explore options to improve our liquidity on Euronext Paris. We remain optimistic that we can enhance our liquidity on Euronext to allow more European investors access to our shares. We will continue to keep you updated on our progress as we move forward. 
With that, I would like to now introduce our Chairman and CEO, Andreas Fibig.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I would like to start by providing an executive overview of our operational performance this quarter. In addition, similar how we structured the quarter 2 conference call, I want to provide an update on the execution of our 4-pillar Visio
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I would like to start by providing an executive overview of our operational performance this quarter. In addition, similar how we structured the quarter 2 conference call, I want to provide an update on the execution of our 4-pillar Vision 2020 strategy. Once finished, I will ask Alison to review our financial results in greater detail, including the specifics on each business unit as well as our cash flow statement and our outlook for the balance of the year.
I'm pleased to report that our financial results for the third quarter accelerated versus our second quarter performance, both in terms of currency-neutral sales and currency neutral adjusted operating profit growth, as we continue to benefit from diversity of our business as well as our recent acquisitions. 
Currency-neutral sales in the third quarter improved 7%, including approximately 3 percentage points relating to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors and Lucas Meyer Cosmetics. Organic top line performance, which increased 4% this quarter, continue to be driven by new wins, particularly in Fragrance Compounds where the contribution of new wins were at the highest level in nearly 2 years.
This was favorable to profitability as adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS both grew 10% on a currency-neutral basis. On a year-to-date basis, results remained strong, as currency-neutral sales growing 6% comprised of 8% growth in Flavors and 5% growth in Fragrances. 
For the first 9 months in 2015, consolidated adjusted operating profit increased 9% on currency-neutral basis, driven by sales growth, the benefit of productivity programs and manufacturing and our sales cost leverage. 
Complementing our expansion in gross margin and adjusted operating profit margin, lower interest expense, a more favorable effect of tax rate and a reduction of our shares outstanding led to an 11% increase on our currency-neutral adjusted EPS.
On a strategic perspective, I would like to talk about a couple of areas. In the areas where we are targeting a market leadership position defined by #1 or 2 market share position, we believe we are taking the right steps to deliver on our ambition of accelerated growth. 
In North America, the Flavors team has done a nice job integrating our recent acquisition of Ottens Flavors, leveraging their defined go-to-market strategy, which focuses on winning these key regional accounts in the U.S. Our Flavors North America business was up 19%. 
In Flavors Latin America, our proprietary delivery system continues to perform well as evident with its eighth consecutive quarter of double-digit growth. In the third quarter, growth was very strong, up 20% on a currency-neutral basis. 
Within Fragrance, North America Fragrance Compounds was 7%, with 8% growth in Consumer Fragrances and a 4% growth in Fine Fragrance. The quarter's [ph] subcategory performance that were most notable in North America were Hair Care and Home Care, both of which grew double digits, plus Fabric Care, which grew high single digits.
In the third quarter, China Fragrances, another area where we have ambitions to accelerate gross, was 6% on a currency-neutral basis as we continue to have success with many of the strong regional Consumer Fragrance brands. 
From a category perspective, Home Care, another area of focus for us, improved high single digits globally on a currency-natural basis led by double-digit growth in North America and Latin America. 
Delivery systems across both Flavors and Fragrance continues to drive growth, with strong trends in Fabric Care and Beverage continued in the third quarter, driven by our industry-leading encapsulation technology in Fragrances and proprietary delivery systems in Flavors.
Fabric Care grew double digits on a currency-neutral basis in the third quarter with all geographic markets posting strong growth. This is a direct result of our differentiated encapsulation technology. 
Given our success in Fabric Care, we have begun to expand into other categories as well. In the third quarter, while still early in terms of strategic execution, we have seen strong results in encapsulation-related sales and Toiletries and Home Care, both, which grew double digits. 
Supporting the expansion of this technology into more categories, our R&D team developed the next-generation capsule technology that allows us to further penetrate personal care applications. This technology should allow us to efficiently customize solutions to deliver Fragrance at the points desired by consumers.
In Fragrances, building on our legacy of pioneering first, one of our Vision 2020 goals is to launch more new captive molecules to give our perfumers a competitive edge when creating the next-generation fragrance. Tracking this initiative, we have recently launched 2 new, highly anticipated ingredients to our perfumers: customer food [ph] , which is a high-impact complex fruity note with spicy undertones, and Crystalyx, which is a watery [ph] refresh note, to be used is internally by our perfumers as exclusive IFF molecules, which we are not selling externally.
And as we look to the fourth quarter, we expect to commercialize the 2 additional molecules, which would bring our commercialize molecules to 4 this year. If successful, this would effectively put us on track to double our annual Fragrance molecule output average order plus decayed, providing us with greater confidence in our accelerated growth ambition.
As I mentioned moments ago in Flavors, our proprietary delivery system continues to perform well. This technology is expanding beyond just Latin America, this proprietary delivery system related sales growing strong double digits globally. 
Sales of our Sweetness and Savory Modulation portfolio continue to produce strong results, increasing strong double digits. 
The categories where we had the most success were Savory, Dairy and Beverage, as our innovative solutions are allowing our customers to meet the demands of the consumers who are looking for better-for-you products, including reduced sugar and salt. 
To complement this, I'm pleased to announce that we have also commercialized a new natural taste modulator, the second one this year, which is a [indiscernible] designed to reduce the salt perception without changing the product's acidity, particularly useful for yogurts and juice applications. This addition will strengthen our modulation capabilities as it provides our Flavors a more competitive palate to build winning solutions.
Building on a very robust technology pipeline is critical. The third quarter is an example that we are making strong progress against key initiatives that will lead to greater differentiation and ultimately, accelerated growth.
In addition to the strides we have made from market share and innovation perspective, we also made progress in our never-ending quest to become our customers' partner of choice. To meet the growing trends in Naturals, in October 2015, IFF LMR Naturals received its 4th For Life Social Responsibility designation, this time in cooperation with Vetiver partner in Haiti. The For Life designation recognizes an organization's adherence to specific sustainability criteria, including transparency, environmental responsibility, fair working conditions and positive relations with producers and local communities. This recognition comes after certification of IFF-LMR Naturals for the rose supply chain in Turkey and its patchouli and basil supply chain in Madagascar.
 
When it comes to sustainability, we won't accept the status quo. Recently, we became the first Flavors and Fragrance company to join DFS and enter a new, growing consortium of a multinational companies committed to ensuring sustainable practices throughout the supply chain.
We also are recognized by the CDP earning a perfect score of 100 in disclosure and an A in performance for its strategies and actions to mitigate climate change. Sustainability is a foundational to our Vision 2020 business strategy, and we are committed to embedding sustainability throughout business throughout our business practices and our corporate culture for the years to come.
We also won the North American innovation award with one of our largest Flavors customers, which we recognized as partners for their thought leadership. In addition, Este Lauder also presented us with their Supplier's Excellence Award, an achievement designed to acknowledge their top-performing business partners.
I'm pleased to also announce that at the 2015 in-cosmetics Asia, Lucas Meyer Cosmetics won the Gold award for the Innovation Zone Best Active Ingredients with Exo-P, a competitive ingredient designed to rapidly improve dull skin for healthy looking complexion in only 7 days, and also won the Gold award of r Innovation Zone Best Functional Ingredient with Lecigel, an ingredient scientifically measured using various techniques developed by specialists in psychology and neuroscience, which provides a positive emotion upon application.
With a focus on the future and in terms of the business participation in the years to come, we also reaffirmed and expanded our core list status with key Flavors customers, 2 based in North America and 1 globally, and also a large Fragrances customer in the third quarter.
As you know, core lists are paramount to winning future business within our industry. Being added to a new core list shows that we are able to bring the right R&D capabilities, consumer insights, regulatory requirements and customers' trust needed to create the winning products in the marketplace.
During the second and third quarter, we completed 2 acquisitions, with focus on strengthening and expanding our portfolio. I'm pleased to report that both acquisitions are performing very well. Ottens Flavors' organic sales on a standalone basis increased low double digits, above our North America-based business, which improved substantially. And Lucas Meyer's Cosmetics achieved strong double digit currency neutral sales growth on a standalone basis. We believe these results are good indication that we are putting our capital to work to drive accelerated performance in terms of growth and returns.
Following the end of the third quarter, we also announced the partnership with Vapor Communications to pioneer the digital future of scent, combining certain Vapor software and hardware scent platform with IFF scent technology and expertise. The collaboration is anticipated to bring mobile scent experiences to consumers. And while this is an initial step, we believe the technologies developed by Vapor Communications will play an important role in our larger digital scent journey in Vision 2020.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Alison, who will take you through the financials in greater detail.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andreas. Looking at our third quarter results, similar to what I did on our Q2 conference call, I want to continue to lay out a bridge from our adjusted financial results to our adjusted currency-neutral results.In the first column, which is
componenttext:
Thank you, Andreas. Looking at our third quarter results, similar to what I did on our Q2 conference call, I want to continue to lay out a bridge from our adjusted financial results to our adjusted currency-neutral results.
In the first column, which is inclusive of currency, sales contracted by 1%, while adjusted operating profit increased 7% and adjusted EPS grew 5%.
Consistent with what we communicated previously, in the third quarter, we benefited from our euro transactional hedging program, which ultimately protected our euro-denominated profit. Including this benefit, our growth rate in terms of adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS accelerated to 7% and 5% versus the 1% and 4% we reported in the first half, respectively. Yet, even with the benefits of hedging, foreign exchange still proved to be a headwind in the third quarter as the U.S. dollar remained strong against many global currencies. 
From a sales adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS perspective, currency represented an 8, 3 and 5 percentage point impact, respectively. 
On a currency-neutral basis, we continue to deliver strong results, achieving leverage within our P&L with the sales improving 7% and adjusted operating profit growing 10%. The increase in adjusted operating profit was driven by gross margin expansion and cost leverage, which led to an approximately 50-basis-point improvement in currency neutral adjusted operating profit margin.
Currency neutral adjusted EPS also improved by 10% as the year-over-year decrease in our average shares outstanding resulting from our share repurchase program offset a slightly higher effective tax rate and an increase in interest expense relating to both of our acquisitions. The acquisitions we made earlier this year are adding to our performance, evidenced that we are investing in strategic value-add opportunities that deliver high return. 
In the third quarter, the acquisitions of Ottens and Lucas Meyers added approximately 3 points to currently currency neutral sales growth, about 2 points to currency neutral adjusted operating profit and 3 points to currency neutral adjusted EPS growth. It should be noted that the amortization of intangibles relating to the Ottens and Lucas Meyer acquisition represented about $3.5 million in the quarter.
If we add this back to understand the cash component of the business, adjusted operating profit and adjusted EPS growth would have improved another 2 percentage points to 12%, respectively, on a currency-neutral basis.
[indiscernible] here, I would like to provide you with some insight into the trends we saw throughout the quarter. In September, while at a sell side Investor Conference, I made some cautionary comments relating to our organic business. Following the Chinese currency devaluation, we saw several customers take a more cautious approach to managing their inventory, which ultimately meant sequential softness as we progress through the quarter. This perpetuated, particularly in emerging markets, which while still positive up 3% in Q3 were slower than our first half performance of 8%, despite relatively strong performance in Latin America. And while we remain fully committed to the long-term growth of these key market, in the short-term, we are working to manage the uncertainty and focusing on the leverage we can pull to deliver results and strengthen our business.
Fortunately, we experienced strong orders in the last week of the quarter leading to the 4% organic growth rate we reported in Q3 ahead of where we thought we would finish the quarter.
Turning to business unit performance. Flavors posted its 43rd consecutive quarter of growth, increasing 8%, including approximately 4.5 percentage points relating to the acquisitions of Ottens Flavors. All categories experienced broad-based growth with the strongest results in Beverage and Dairy.
In our Europe, Africa and Middle East regions, sales increased 4%, led by high single-digit growth in Beverage. Western Europe reported the highest growth, improving 9% driven by strong new win performance.
North America grew 19%, reflecting additional sales related to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors and high double-digit growth in Dairy. If we exclude the benefit of Ottens organic performance improved sequentially versus Q2, up low single-digits.
Latin America increased 20% as all categories reported positive growth. The strong double-digit trend in Beverage continued for the eighth consecutive quarter, led by our proprietary delivery system. Savory and Dairy also grew double digits as a result of strong new win performance, which leverages that proprietary delivery systems as well as our modulation portfolio.
Greater Asia remains constant, as growth in Indonesia, India, Singapore and Japan was offset by softness in China, which was primarily driven by a challenging economic environment.
Flavors currency neutral segment profit improved approximately 9% as gross margin expansion and cost and productivity benefits more than offset the inclusion of amortization of intangibles related to the acquisition of Ottens Flavors. This led to a 10-basis-point improvement in operating profit margin, despite incremental costs in Q3 relating to the China issue. If we exclude this impact, our operating margin would have expanded by 80 basis points in the third quarter or growth would have been 12%. It should be noted however, that we expect a portion of this expense to continue as we work through this issue. Specifically, in Q4, we would expect the similar impact in terms of expense as we experienced in Q3. 
Fragrances' currency neutral sales improved 6%, including approximately 2 percentage points associated with the acquisition of Lucas Meyer Cosmetics with all regions posting growth, led by high single-digit growth in Latin America/and mid-single-digit improvement in Greater Asia.
From a category perspective, Fine Fragrance was up 1% led by Europe, Africa and the Middle East, which improved 5% as a result of very strong pipeline of new wins including Olympia by Popper upon, [indiscernible] by Procter & Gamble, La Via Est Belle by Lancome from L'Oreal and Jimmy Choo by [indiscernible] 
In Latin America, economic conditions, particularly in Brazil, continue to have an impact on discretionary spending and ultimately, our Fine Fragrance performance. Yet, while sales were down, they improved versus the second quarter. And even as economies fall, we continue to see our win rate remain high, which we believe will support our market leadership position as the economy stabilizes.
I also wanted to put our Fine Fragrance results in Greater Asia into perspective relative to our global Fragrance business. Proportionately, Greater Asia Fine Fragrances represented approximately 2% of our global Fine Fragrance sales, which means quarterly order patterns can have a substantial impact on growth rates as it did in Q1 when Fine Fragrance in Greater Asia was up almost 40%.
And as the market is relatively small in terms of per capita uses now, we believe it will increase over time as we stated in our Vision 2020 strategy. 
For the 16th consecutive quarter, Consumer Fragrances continue to grow, up 7%, with mid- to high single digits in every region and broad-based category growth led by double-digit growth in Fabric Care and high single-digit growth in Hair Care.
In Fabric, thanks in large part to a local knowledge of the consumer and our encapsulated technology, growth was as strongest in Greater Asia where we are winning with local customers. And in Hair Care, growth was of the best in Latin America, as we have the ability to offer exceptional Fragrances in nontraditional category that meets the consumer's desire for lower-cost alternatives.
Fragrance Ingredients sales were up 6%, driven by the acquisition of Lucas Meyer Cosmetics, which closed/on July 30. Sales related to cosmetic actives grew high double digits in Brazil, Japan, Indonesia and the U.S., all a result of new wins. 
Our base Fragrance Ingredients business, which as a reminder, are the external sales that we do not use for our internal company's production remains soft, reflecting more challenging work conditions, including our largest Fragrance Ingredients customer, rationalizing their portfolio as well as our prioritization of capacity to further strengthen our internal Fragrance Compounds business as evidenced by high single-digit internal demand growth.
On a profit perspective, Fragrance currency-neutral segment's profit improved approximately 15%, driven by volume growth and benefits from cost and productivity initiatives. This performance, plus lower incentive compensation expense, was over 150-basis-point improvement in operating profit margin. 
From a cash flow perspective, our core working capital levels continue to show improvement as a percentage of sales versus the same period in 2014 as our 5-quarter rolling average figure through the end of the third quarter was down 80 basis points to approximately 28.8% of our trailing 12-month sales.
All of our gains versus the first 9 months of 2014 came from lower payables, as our days payable outstanding increased 9% versus the same period a year ago. 
Operating cash flow from operations at the end of the third quarter was $295 million, including an incremental $27 million pension contributions so far this year. Excluding the incremental pension contribution, operating cash flow would have increased $322 million or 40 basis points in terms of adjusted operating cash flow as a percentage of sales and 13.6% during the first 9 months of 2014 to 14% for the equivalent period in 2015.
Looking at our uses of cash. Capital expenditure on a year-to-date basis is $67 million or 2.9% of sales as we continue to make investments to support our growth initiatives, principally as we finish our plants in Turkey and Indonesia. And while we are a little low on the capital spend year-to-date relative to our full year guidance, we expect to finish approximately 4.5% as spending traditionally falls through during the fourth quarter each year.
For cash returned to shareholders, we expect to continue to deliver a total payout ratio in line with our 50% to 60% target, all while maintaining financial flexibility to capitalize the planned organic growth opportunities and value-creating M&A. 
Dividend payments year-to-date has been $114 million, following our 20% increase this past August. Share repurchases at the end of the quarter were $81 million, allowing us to buy back approximately 726,000 shares at an average price of $111.88 per share. Please note that as of Friday, we have repurchased approximately $21 million of shares since the end of the quarter, bringing our year-to-date total to $102 million.
From a guidance perspective, we are reconfirming our full year 2015 guidance despite the challenging year-ago fourth quarter comparison, which includes approximately 200 basis points of growth related to the 53rd week as well as continued market uncertainty, which is leading to volatility in order patterns for many of our multinational customers.
Despite continued growth in Latin America and Europe, Africa and the Middle East, driven by new wins, our core Flavors business is expected to be soft in the fourth quarter. 
In North America, we expect pressure due a to higher level of volume erosion as businesses we won in previous years are not performing at the same levels that they have historically. We are also seeing general line weakness in North America with several of our food and beverage customers reporting volume challenges. 
In Greater Asia, we expect similar trends through the third quarter as we believe the economic uncertainty in China will continue to impact our business.
In core Fragrances, we expect continued pressure in Fragrance Ingredients, primarily related to the largest customer continuing its rationalization of their portfolio. 
In Fragrance Compounds, we expect that our strong year-ago comparison, the weakness in the Brazilian economy and our strong year-to-date performance, particularly in Consumer Fragrances, will lead to growth moderating in Q4. Fortunately, we expect to benefit from our recent acquisitions, which we believe should lead to moderate currency neutral sales growth in the fourth quarter.
In terms of profitability, on a full year basis, we continue to believe we can achieve approximately 9% growth on a currency-neutral basis. The drivers of the profitability performance includes top line growth, benefits of productivity initiatives, lower incentive compensation expense and the inclusion of acquisition.
Stretching our [ph] performance to include the impact of currency, the strengthening U.S. dollar versus many global currencies will have an impact. The weakening euro versus the U.S. dollar, which represents our large currency exposure, at about 40% of operating profit, is expected to have the greatest impact. In addition, several other currencies, while small in terms of profitability exposure, has all weakened considerably versus the U.S. dollar and are collectively pressuring profitability. Mitigating this exposure, we expect approximately a 3 percentage point gain from our transactional euro hedging program. Incorporating the foreign exchange impact on our full year guidance, we would expect reported sales to be down approximately 1%, including approximately a 7-percentage-point impact from currency as we do not hedge our translational exposure. From an adjusted operating profit perspective, we expect about a 4% increase, despite an approximately 5 percentage point headwind of currency. 
With that, I would like to turn the call back over to Andreas.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alison. I briefly want to reiterate that despite ongoing volatility in several key markets around the world, we were able to move a strong financial results in the third quarter, thanks in large part to the diversity of our business as well as
componenttext:
Thank you, Alison. I briefly want to reiterate that despite ongoing volatility in several key markets around the world, we were able to move a strong financial results in the third quarter, thanks in large part to the diversity of our business as well as the benefits associated with our recent acquisitions. Also, based on our strong year-to-date results and our outlook for the fourth quarter, we continue to believe we can deliver 6% currency neutral sales growth and approximately 9% adjusted operating profit growth, both on a currency-neutral basis.
Going forward, continuing our execution of Vision 2020 is top priority for us. Vision 2020 is focused on increasing differentiation, accelerating profitable growth and creating shareholder value, all 3 of which we believe are achievable in the years to come.
With that, I would now like to open the call for questions.

And so we expect Q1 to be challenging, but as we traditionally do, expect to shave more in our February call on reporting our 2016 full year guidance.

componenttextpreview: So Mark, let me talk first about -- so in Q3, our adjusted gross profit margin expanded 170 basis points, and this was driven by our currency hedging benefits as we hedge our raw material purchases to protect our transactional exposure as well as our cost
componenttext: So Mark, let me talk first about -- so in Q3, our adjusted gross profit margin expanded 170 basis points, and this was driven by our currency hedging benefits as we hedge our raw material purchases to protect our transactional exposure as well as our cost of productivity savings, volume growth and mix improvement. In Q3, there was roughly $9.5 million benefit from our hedge, which was included in the gross -- in our gross profit. This account has been for the majority o the from a cause of a but there was also benefit as I mentioned, cost of productivity savings, volume growth and mix improvement. As we move into Q4, we expect our currency hedging benefit to be a little less than half of the expansion in Q4, with the other half coming from cost of productivity savings initiatives, modest volume growth and M&A. We believe that our -- there is sustainability of that gross margin expansion excluding the FX hedge as we enter into Q4. As we look in 2016, from a raw materials perspective, based on what we've seen so far, it's similar to 2015 where we've seen natural are up, synthetics are slightly down and if anything, we're probably flat to slightly up.

componenttext: So Lauren, let me talk a bit about that. And so as we indicated at our Investor Day that we intend to finance our M&A activity through balance sheet leverage and so between us and Lucas Meyer's acquisition, we executed about $500 million in acquisitions. Initially, these are paid for using our existing credit facility and on-hand cash and now, we're looking at longer term financing opportunities to better align our maturities with the nature of those acquisitions. So in September, we entered into interest swaps in anticipation of a long-term debt financing and the deferred charges in that table in our 10-Q are being accounted for right now is a hedging instrument as they're related to these swaps. We still are in of the process of evaluating our options for financing, and at this point, we haven't finalized the timing or nature of the financing, and we expect to have more clarity on that in Q1 of next year.

componenttext: Mike, this is Andreas, I'm taking that. What we see that for some of our of our global customers or other volumes are slowing, but it's actually not one-fits-all answer because we see in some areas. like still Latin America on the Flavors side, we see strong growth as in the third quarter, which is really, really double-digit. We see countries in Asia with strong growth for both businesses. And we see Europe at least on for our business recovering as well. So at the end of the day, it's a very mixed picture region-by-region. The only thing, which is probably universal is that the volume is, for some of the global customers, is really challenged. So that's how we would comment on that one. So it's very different and it depends also on the technology and let me elaborate on that. If you have a technology that helps view of a technology, which helps the customers to grow the business like our sweetness modulation for example, which we are selling very well, or the encapsulation of the Fragrances side, then the wins are strong and that even against the market a trend make great strides.
